trans-unit.source: Provides access to HTTP request values without triggering ASP.NET request validation.

When ASP.NET reads the values in HTTP request collections (such as the <xref:System.Web.HttpRequest.Form%2A>, <xref:System.Web.HttpRequest.QueryString%2A>, and <xref:System.Web.HttpRequest.Cookies%2A> collections), it performs *request validation*.
During request validation, ASP.NET examines the posted values and determines whether they contain markup, script, or reserved characters.
By default, if ASP.NET detects any of these types of input, it throws an <xref:System.Web.HttpRequestValidationException> exception.
This helps prevent malicious script injection attacks on your website.
However, in some cases, you might want to bypass ASP.NET request validation and allow values that contain markup, script, or reserved characters.

For example, if your application uses a rich-text editor that enables users to submit HTML markup as formatted content, you can use the members of the <xref:System.Web.UnvalidatedRequestValues> class to retrieve the rich-text request values without triggering the default ASP.NET request validation.
In your code, you access members of this class by using the <xref:System.Web.HttpRequest.Unvalidated%2A> property.
If you use this class, you must manually check the data for potential cross-site scripting attacks.
Gets the collection of cookies that the client sent, without triggering ASP.NET request validation.
If you use this property, you must manually check the data for potential cross-site scripting attacks.
The cookies from the HTTP request.
Gets the collection of files that the client uploaded, without triggering ASP.NET request validation.
If you use this property, you must manually check the data for potential cross-site scripting attacks.
The files from the HTTP request.
Gets the collection of form variables that the client submitted, without triggering ASP.NET request validation.
If you use this property, you must manually check the data for potential cross-site scripting attacks.
The form variables from the HTTP request.
Gets the collection of HTTP headers that the client sent, without triggering request validation.
If you use this property, you must manually check the data for potential cross-site scripting attacks.
The headers from the HTTP request.

Gets the specified object from the <xref href="System.Web.HttpRequest.Form"></xref>, <xref href="System.Web.HttpRequest.Cookies"></xref>, <xref href="System.Web.HttpRequest.QueryString"></xref>, or <xref href="System.Web.HttpRequest.ServerVariables"></xref> collection, without triggering ASP.NET request validation.
If you use this property, you must manually check the data for potential cross-site scripting attacks.
The key of the object to retrieve.
The requested object, or `null` if the object is not found.
Gets the virtual path of the requested resource without triggering ASP.NET request validation.
If you use this property, you must manually check the data for potential cross-site scripting attacks.
The virtual path.
Gets additional path information for a resource that has a URL extension, without triggering ASP.NET request validation.
If you use this property, you must manually check the data for potential cross-site scripting attacks.
A string that contains additional path information for a resource.
Gets the collection of HTTP query string variables that the client submitted, without triggering ASP.NET request validation.
If you use this property, you must manually check the data for potential cross-site scripting attacks.
The collection of query string variables sent by the client.
Gets the part of the requested URL that follows the website name, without triggering ASP.NET request validation.
If you use this property, you must manually check the data for potential cross-site scripting attacks.
If the complete request URL is `http://www.contoso.com/default.aspx?id=44`, the value of <xref:System.Web.UnvalidatedRequestValues.RawUrl%2A> is `/default.aspx?id=44`.
The part of the URL that follows the website name.
Gets the URL data for the request without triggering ASP.NET request validation.
If you use this property, you must manually check the data for potential cross-site scripting attacks.
You can retrieve URL data such as the port number, host name, path information, and data about the user from the <xref:System.Uri> object that this property returns.
An object that contains the URL data for the request.
